data.title: Have IBoundingVolume interface for Bounding Frustum/Box/Sphere etc?
data.body:
Hi guys,

I was wondering if we could just go ahead and implement an interface for the Bounding Frustum/Box/Sphere class, which would dictate stuff like Intersect(), Contain(), etc

I don't see any downside and on the upside we can just cast all of these for generic comparisons like
 ((IBoundingVolume) myBoundingVolume).Contains(myVector3);
 or (myBoundingVolume as IBoundingVolume) for that matter

What do you think?

data.title: Android Fullscreen Not Working

Fixes the calculation of loopLength for ADPCM sound files

What this pull request is missing (from my point of view) is a clear distinction between the SoundEffect constructor that supports ADPCM and the one that doesn't.

data.title: Multisampling and RenderTarget2D
data.body: I have spent a lot of time debugging this bug and finally cracked it with DebugView and DirectX Debug Layer. You cannot create a depth stencil view with multisampling if you do not set the underlying texture dimension. This only affects the DirectX version of RenderTarget2D I think.

data.title: Creating RenderTarget2D with RenderTargetUsage crashes with UWP
data.body:
When using the constructor overload for RenderTarget2D that takes a RenderTargetUsage parameter, it crashes on UWP. 

Error:
`An exception of type 'SharpDX.SharpDXException' occurred in SharpDX.dll but was not handled in user code Additional information: HRESULT: [0x80070057], Module: [General], ApiCode: [E_INVALIDARG/Invalid Arguments], Message: Felaktig parameter.`

Felaktig parameter = "Error parameter" or something like that, it's swedish :)

Code Used:
`new RenderTarget2D(graphicsDevice, 512, 512, false, SurfaceFormat.Color, DepthFormat.None, 0, RenderTargetUsage.DiscardContents);`

It doesn't matter what value the RenderTargetUsage enum has.

data.title: Increase functionality and efficiency to Spritebatch via alterations to the Spritefont class
data.body: This maybe a bit early for this post but in consideration of the proposed addition of emoji characters. In #4805 i suppose i should post this as Spritefont is up for changes Ill begin by stating i have reduced the spritefont.DrawInto methods matrix calculations. As a result of trying to allow for a culling boundary rectangle to be added to a custom drawString method. I have come to realize, the Spritefont class is a bit poorly structured in relation to Spritebatch. https://drive.google.com/open?id=0B1zD887frY04bkJkU3hEMmZoT1k Internal Measurestring, Drawinto, Charsource, are tightly coupled and both the Charsource struct in Spritefont and Drawinto are tightly coupled to Spritebatch. Basically Spritefont holds some Spritebatches responsibility were it should not. If we could bypass DrawInto with our own Drawstring then pass the results to DrawInternal.. From this we could then create our own custom methods that manipulate text in unique ways. Even if the above doesn't sound good drawinto could use a tune up. I propose the following be considered, The charsource struct. The internal measurestring . The method Drawinto All be moved to the Spritebatch class. Further that DrawInto is simply a internal Drawstring and it be possibly renamed to reflect that. Also considering the possibility that the struct Charsource maybe redundant as well as it is not preventing garbage from being produced and collected.

data.title: SDL2 2.0.5?
data.body:
Not really an issue, just looking for some info from people in the know.

i am on Linux (Ubuntu 16.04) using the latest develop branch with SDL2. MG warns of SDL2 2.0.4 and cites a global mouse issue, which is exactly what i am currently facing.

So i am looking at where this sdl2 2.0.5 comes from. Latest release is 2.0.4 (bugged version) which is on their site and in the Ubuntu repos. I have also tried cloning their hg repo on a number of occasions and had it fail every time.

If someone could point me in the direction of the source used to fix this issue i would really appreciate it.

data.title: Workaround for converting variable bitrate audio files
data.body:
This fixes #4591 and also fix #4588, at least the original problem.
Basically I have put the call ffmpeg in a loop that tries to convert the file with lower quality each time, if the file can be converted with a lower quality there's a new log message stating it
![audio message](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11319966/14845622/aa0d68c8-0c5f-11e6-9e63-e9b975c735d6.PNG)

Changelog:

AudioContent:
- ConvertFormat() now returns the quality used to convert the file.
- ConvertFormat() will keep lowering the quality used to convert the
  sound file until the conversion succedes or runs out of possible
  qualities, in the latter case still throws the exception

SongProcessor:
- Process(): Updated to receive the used quality, if it is different
  from the original adds a log message

SoundEffectProcessor:
- Process(): Updated to receive the used quality, if it is different
  from the original adds a log message

data.title: Added new design converters and extended the pipeline
data.body: Added Colour and Point designer converters (both used in the pipeline tool) and extended the pipelineTypes so it can be used by external tools (anything that might want to load and use the content project).

data.title: Add NVorbis submodule
data.body: So instead of us having an external .dll dependency we could just include the entire NVorbis source code inside. This will allow for the end user to only have to reference MonoGame.Framework.dll and not have to worry about any other dlls.

data.title: SpriteFont does not support emoji characters
data.body:
The content pipeline tool fails with the following exception when a SpriteFont contains characters from the Unicode emoji character range (surrogate characters):

```
Importer 'FontDescriptionImporter' had unexpected failure!
System.FormatException: String must be exactly one character long.
   at System.Xml.XmlConvert.ToChar(String s)
   at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.Pipeline.Serialization.Intermediate.CharSerializer.Deserialize(String[] inputs, Int32& index)
```

The failing SpriteFont file is attached (built on Windows).

[EmojiSpritefont.zip](https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/files/236848/EmojiSpritefont.zip)

data.title: PresentInterval and IsFixTimeStep are bugged
Remove pointless Mac defines and code

data.title: [DesktopGL] Add Retina support
data.body:
Hello,

I tried to add Hi-DPI / Retina support to the new `SDLGameWindow` but it turns out it is way more complicated than just adding the `Sdl.Window.State.AllowHiDpi` creation flag to the window.

I lack the OS X understanding and unlimited access to a Retina, and I don't get what OS X is expecting when it comes to backbuffer, window and viewport size. Their virtual DPI system is totally different from other systems and the documentation didn't quite helped me. There are some design decisions to take as well, because setting a 2880x1800 resolution may end up to a 1440x900 viewport, which is misleading compared to what XNA users are used to and specific to OS X. Do we want this? Do we need some virtualisation?

Right now, `GraphicsDeviceManager.HardwareModeSwitch = true` renders a black screen on any Retina displays, while the borderless mode displays games only on 1/4th of the screen (on the lower left). This means that it is a regression compared to OpenTK (which was supporting Hi-DPI, but only correctly working with the desktop resolution, or borderless).

I wouldn't mind some help on this front, or any hints on how OS X works with Hi-DPI, OpenGL and SDL2. ( @tomspilman mind adding the "help wanted" tag?)

Note that on Windows, enabling Hi-DPI is as simple as adding a manifest to enable it. No other action is required and it works as expected. I'll push a PR to add this to the DesktopGL template.

@dellis1972 Did you have any issues with Retina on the latest SDL changes?

data.title: Only use Default implementation on older Mac APIs
data.body: This allows Xamarin.Mac to build again without introducing any regressions in the current behaviour.  If we opted for only GamePad.Mac or GamePad.Default to be included in the project, then we'd either introduce regressions for MonoMac or regressions for Xamarin.Mac.

data.title: Improve AssemblyInfo

milestone.title: 3.6 Release
milestone.description: More unit tests, running unit tests on Mac and Linux, SDL2 replacing OpenTK.

data.body:
If you look at our current assembly info files:

https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/develop/MonoGame.Framework/Properties/AssemblyInfo.cs

https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/develop/MonoGame.Framework.Content.Pipeline/Properties/AssemblyInfo.cs

we need to make improvements to them.

First for some reason the `AssemblyDescription` which we seem to be setting correct doesn't appear in the final executable:

![assinfo](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/103522/14770975/59bb5a2e-0a43-11e6-89f0-5994395aa376.PNG)

That needs to be fixed.... could be the build server is at blame here, but i don't know.

We should remove the `#if`s in there too and instead go with something like the partial class technique with new files `AssemblyInfo.Windows.cs`, `AssemblyInfo.iOS.cs`, `AssemblyInfo.Android.cs` etc.  This allows for PS4 and other platforms to add their own custom assembly attributes.

The `Copyright  2011-2016` should be changed to `Copyright  2009-2016 MonoGame Team` which matches when the MonoGame project started.

We should set `AssemblyCompany` to `MonoGame Team`.

We should set the `AssemblyTrademark` to `MonoGame is a registered trademark of the MonoGame Team`.

Also everything discussed here should be done for the pipeline assembly info as well.  We should be sure that the new PCL portable assemblies have their info modified to mark them clearly as PCL and not for a particular platform.

Any other cleanups we need to do here?

Fixes #4783

SDL does not register the new size until the next Update loop so we need to keep our own copy of them.

data.title: Why stick with Content Pipeline?
data.body:
This is super annoying for lot of assets, sounds, etc.. and specially for fonts

Is it possible to let us load assets from stream and stay away from that content pipeline annoying thing?

Also for fonts, why not being able to simply use TTF fonts instead of that xml thing?

Something like:

var fontGen = new FontGenerator("path/of/ttf/font");
fontGen.size...
fontGen.spacing..
fontGen.outline..

var spriteFont = fontGen.Build();

Far easier and much more logical that the xml mess

I hope i don't sound too rude but its been 1 week since i try to find a good solution for spritefont without that content pipleline, i want manage my assets as i want not forced to use a specific app

data.title: Common Bin Folder
data.body:
Currently the structure of our output bin folders is this:
- `MonoGame.Framework/bin`
- `MonoGame.Framework.Content.Pipeline/bin`
- `Tools/2MGFX/bin`
- `Tools/MGCB/bin`
- `Tools/Pipeline/bin`
- `Test/bin`

And once https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/issues/4794 we have yet another.

I've seen other projects invert this to have a common root binary folder:
- `bin\MonoGame.Framework`
- `bin\MonoGame.Framework.Content.Pipeline`
- `bin\Tools\2MGFX`
- `bin\Tools\MGCB`
- `bin\Tools\Pipeline`
- `bin\Test`

This way there is one root when you need to copy/delete/move/archive/etc.

Is this a good idea for MonoGame?  Are there downsides to this?

Should we apply the same technique to the `obj` folder too?

Also should we go further?  For example in that new structure we still end up with multiple copies of `MonoGame.Framework.dll` as each of those assemblies references it and pulls it in.  Should we look to remove this redundancy further by doing:
- `bin\Framework` <- MonoGame.Framework and MonoGame.Framework.Net
- `bin\Pipeline` <- MonoGame.Framework.Content.Pipeline and deps.
- `bin\Tools` <- 2MGFX, MGCB, Pipeline
- `bin\Test`

Thoughts?

data.title: Move MonoGame.Framework.Net to its own folder
data.body:
We want to move the code for the MonoGame.Framework.Net assembly into its own top level folder like we do for ``.  This would give us three top level folders where the core assembly code is found:
- MonoGame.Framework
- MonoGame.Framework.Net
- MonoGame.Framework.Content.Pipeline 

During the moving of this code _NO_ other code changes should occur.

The list of all the code files that need to be moved can be found here:

Note that the `MonoGame.Framework\Properties\AssemblyInfo.cs` should be copied and modified for the new assembly:

https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/develop/MonoGame.Framework/Properties/AssemblyInfo.cs

Also the `Path` in the protobuild definition needs to be changed:
  https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/develop/Build/Projects/MonoGame.Framework.Net.definition#L2

The installers for Mac, Linux, and Windows will need to be updated to pull from the new output bin folders.

Finally the configuration of the build server will have to change to pull from the new bin folders as well.

The idea was originally proposed in https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/issues/3055.

This also solves https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/issues/2981 and https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/issues/3480 if they haven't been resolved by fixes in XamarinStudio already.

data.title: Add Android gamepad support
data.body: Reopening a pull request to add native gamepad support for Android.

data.title: XmlImporter requires elements in order. XNA does not.
data.body:
I've come across a strange issue building a bunch of XML files with the MonoGame content pipeline. 
For various XML files, I get an InvalidContentException, telling me I'm missing a required element.
After reassuring myself that the element in question was indeed present in the XML file and resided at the expected level, I tried reordering the elements, and, lo and behold, the error disappeared.

I had previously built the same XML files with the XNA content pipeline and never had an issue there.
